div.p: From Alexander Macdonald to Charles Topp
E98/10135, unit 972, VPRS 3992/P inward registered correspondence, VA 475 Chief Secretary's Department, Public Record Office, Victoria.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: MS bears the illustrated letterhead of the Victoria Branch of the Society.

div.p: Memorial to the late Baron Von Mueller
I have the honor by direction of the President and members of the Memorial Committee to request a reply to the following query viz

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0.4929in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.4929in;

div.p: The amount promised by the Government towards the erection of a suitable Public Memorial to the late Baron Von Mueller — apart altogether from any amount promised to be paid to the Trustees of the estate of the late Baron.

The Committee will meet on Wednesday the 6th Inst at 4 pm. and the favour of your reply in time for the meeting will greatly oblige.
On 5 October 1897, Topp minuted: 'Professor Spencer & Mr Frost called on me yesterday in reference to a letter by the Rev W. Potter in the Age stating that the Government had promised the Trustees of the late Govt Botanist a contribution towards the erection of a memorial [tombstone deleted]; they stated that they understood the Government contribution was to be paid to the Memorial Committee of which Sir John Madden is chairman; I told them that a letter had been sent to Mr Potter to that effect — see copy of letter dated 17/3/97 [on] E3566. [See notes to W. Potter to G. Turner, 9 March 1897] I suppose there is no objection to the Secretary of the Memorial Committee being informed to the same effect (that is that the Govt contribution will be paid to the Memorial Committee). Can any definite amount be specified? I understood the Memorial Committee will endeavour to collect an amount which may allow of some further & more useful memorial than a monument'.
The Premier, G. Turner, replied on 6 October: 'Any amount will be paid to the Memorial Committee but until I know what Committee propose to do & what funds are required & how to be raised I cannot promise any definite amt'.
Topp minuted on 7 October: 'Inform the Hon Secy of the Memorial Committee in accordance with the Premier's last minute'. A letter was sent on 11 October.
On 5 November Turner minuted: 'Mr Potter called on me a day or two ago — I refused to discuss the matter or give him any promise — he afterwards returned & produced letter 17/3/97 & said he intended to use the promise therein when writing to the press — he informed me that as the Committee had not moved on this matter he considered the Executors should do so'. A copy of the letter in question is in the file; it clearly states that the money in question would be paid to the Memorial Committee, not to the Executors.
